articles.headline: A Culture Warrior Goes Quiet: DeSantis Dodges Questions on Abortion Plans
articles.snippet: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida faces political pressure from Republicans to further curb abortions — and risks to his re-election campaign and any presidential aspirations if he goes too far.
articles.abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida faces political pressure from Republicans to further curb abortions — and risks to his re-election campaign and any presidential aspirations if he goes too far.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court erased the constitutional right to an abortion last month, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida was among the many Republicans who celebrated. “The prayers of millions have been answered,” he tweeted.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Patricia Mazzei and Michael C. Bender

articles.headline: Abortion Insurance Coverage Is Now Much More Complicated
articles.snippet: In the wake of the Supreme Court ruling, abortion benefits will depend even more on where a woman lives and who provides her insurance.
articles.abstract: In the wake of the Supreme Court ruling, abortion benefits will depend even more on where a woman lives and who provides her insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before the constitutional right to an abortion was struck down last month, health insurance coverage for it was spotty. Abortion benefits largely depended on where a woman lived or whom she worked for.

articles.headline: Twitter Sues Musk After He Tries Backing Out of $44 Billion Deal
articles.snippet: The question of whether Elon Musk must buy Twitter, as he agreed to do in April, is headed to a court in Delaware.
articles.abstract: The question of whether Elon Musk must buy Twitter, as he agreed to do in April, is headed to a court in Delaware.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter sued Elon Musk on Tuesday to force the billionaire to complete his $44 billion acquisition of the company, setting the stage for a prolonged legal battle over the fate of the social media service.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: For Blind Internet Users, the Fix Can Be Worse Than the Flaws
articles.snippet: Companies say their A.I.-powered tools are the best way to fix accessibility problems online, but many blind people find they make websites harder to use.
articles.abstract: Companies say their A.I.-powered tools are the best way to fix accessibility problems online, but many blind people find they make websites harder to use.
articles.lead_paragraph: Patrick Perdue, a radio enthusiast who is blind, regularly shopped for equipment through the website of Ham Radio Outlet. The website’s code allowed him to easily move through the sections of each page with his keyboard, his screen reader speaking the text.

articles.headline: In a Post-Roe World, the Future of Digital Privacy Looks Even Grimmer
articles.snippet: The sheer amount of tech tools and knowledge required to discreetly seek an abortion underlines how wide open we are to surveillance.
articles.abstract: The sheer amount of tech tools and knowledge required to discreetly seek an abortion underlines how wide open we are to surveillance.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Elite Colleges’ Quiet Fight to Favor Alumni Children
articles.snippet: Colleges like Yale and Harvard give a boost to legacy applicants. But with affirmative action under attack, that tradition may become harder to defend.
articles.abstract: Colleges like Yale and Harvard give a boost to legacy applicants. But with affirmative action under attack, that tradition may become harder to defend.
articles.lead_paragraph: Describing its incoming class of 2025, Yale boasted that its students hailed from 48 states, 68 countries and 1,221 high schools. What’s more, the university announced last year, 51 percent of the class identified as students of color.

articles.headline: Israel Works With Arab Allies to Down Drones, in Sign of Growing Ties
articles.snippet: The destruction of Iranian drones last year was an early example of a new regional military project that President Biden is trying to shore up during his Middle East visit.
articles.abstract: The destruction of Iranian drones last year was an early example of a new regional military project that President Biden is trying to shore up during his Middle East visit.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — In the skies east of Israel, a few minutes before 2 a.m., four Israeli pilots scanned the horizon for two unmanned aircraft that were heading toward Israel from Iran. Suddenly, the pilots saw them — two triangular drones, each roughly eight yards wide, speeding westward.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: Airlines’ Challenge Is Cutting Costs, Not Filling Seats
articles.snippet: U.S. carriers see no slowdown in demand, despite unease about the economy. But problems with staffing and operations are eating into profits.
articles.abstract: U.S. carriers see no slowdown in demand, despite unease about the economy. But problems with staffing and operations are eating into profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is little sign that higher fares or recession worries are curbing the pent-up demand for air travel. But higher expenses and staffing shortages are hampering the nation’s airlines as they seek to take full advantage of the rebound.

articles.headline: Euro Falls to Equal the U.S. Dollar for the First Time in 20 Years
articles.snippet: In recent months, pressure on the euro has been mounting while investors have been flocking to the U.S. dollar, a haven in times of economic upheaval.
articles.abstract: In recent months, pressure on the euro has been mounting while investors have been flocking to the U.S. dollar, a haven in times of economic upheaval.

articles.headline: Gates Foundation Adds $20 Billion to Its Coffers
articles.snippet: The organization, still run by Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates, will eventually spend $9 billion a year, up from $6 billion, on causes like global health and education.
articles.abstract: The organization, still run by Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates, will eventually spend $9 billion a year, up from $6 billion, on causes like global health and education.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the news emerged last year that Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates were divorcing, the question of whether their foundation would lose ready access to its founders’ substantial resources quickly arose.
